bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 14, 1947

div1.p: Truby tries to figure out from a photograph the exact room in which Reed died in Washington, D.C. Knowing that the Lazear notebook would answer very important questions regarding Reed's Preliminary Report, he also discusses various ways to get it from the Carroll family.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 14, 1947
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
Jan. 14/47
Dear Col. Hench.
div1.p:
I am sorry I have been so
long in answering your letter of Dec. 19,
but I could not get the info. you
wanted from Mrs Gilhus until she had
time to get her affairs partly settled.

I had a nice phone conversation
with her yesterday and she will look
for the photos Gilhus showed me a couple
of days before his death. They are more important
to you than the small album. The letter you
can keep. I will return it soon with
comments on things I know about.

We have been busy & very gay throughout
the holiday season. My son Jack flew in
from Honolulu. Mrs Truby, Elizabeth and I
were going out to a New Year's eve party
and were going down in our Elevator
to take a taxi. At the lobby floor I opened
the door and there stood Jack. Of course
he was astounded to see us going out and
we were just as much surprised. After
leaving his baggage in our apt. he went with
us to the party and after that he was
taken by some of his friends to a big deb.
affair at the St. Frances. Home at 4 a.m.
AC
T
That is the way it went while he
was here. He was in Honolulu on
the Tokyo swimming team and made
a 3d place, which pleased him greatly
as he was not in training. When the races
were over he hopped a clipper for home here.
He should benow be, in Tokyo about now again.

Thanks for the photos of the W. R. Memorial
Bd. They are good, but you should have
been included. I guess that I am the only
Ex. member living. I consider you
a first class choice for membership
as nearly all the others are getting quite
feeble and many changes will occur
in the next few yrs.

I can't give you any info. re the
apt. house on 19thst. where Reed & Kean
lived in 1902. But the Reed's are probably
right in their statment about which
apt they occupied.

The photo of the former “U.S.A. General
Hospital” at Washington Bks. is confusing
in that the porches have been screened and it is
not a front view. Besides I can't understand
the building at the far end. See photo incl.
I could show you the exact room if I were
there. I may go east to way 50th med. Runion
of my Class in June. Prehaps you can be there
at that time too and we could investigate various
things. By the way I have written Kean & Ireland
and suggested that the S.G. try to get Carroll
to give Dr. Carroll's books & papers to the Library.
George Carroll may be having delusions of
possible persecution because his father had
3
things that belonged to the Govt. If he
were properly approached, and all fear
driven out of his head, he might consent
to give the things to the Library. Of course
it should be stressed that they would be in
Dr Carroll's special space and displayed
in his honor. He might even be bribed to do
this with his estimate of the value of the things.
In the first talk with Carroll, Lazear's notebook
would not have to be mentioned and he might
be off guard and amenable to reason.

I am especially anxious for you to get
that notebook for I am so certain that
my statements about it are correct. Reed
depended so much on the dates in it
when writing the preliminary report; and
of all the things in my book I am most
anxious to have my notebook story confirmed.

Have you read M.B. Grosvenor's article
on Cuba in the Jan. number of the National
Geographic Mag.? I was much interested
since I have been over most of that ground.
He shows pictures of some of the places in
Trinadad which I visited. They were all deserted
in 1900 but he did not mention that.

I think that plate XVII P.40 shows the one
that I went through. It still looks badly
worn & weather beaten. Soleded (p. 30) was
about 12 miles from Rowell Bks. and Mr Atkins
used to have us over there frequently for week
ends. He was a principal stockholder of the sugar
AC
T
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
Central at Soledad and spent his winters
there. He appreciated the value of U.S. troops
so near him and did his best to
show his appreciation gratitude. We
were royally entertained. It was just
a nice horseback ride from our post.

What a great amount of time you must
have put on the Lazear family history.
It is fine but I can't add a thing except
about the funeral of Lazear which took place
“the next day” (Sept. 26th, p.m.) I am
returning it herewith, under separate cover

I have had a letter from Lampson and
he promises to stop in here when it
is possible to do so.

You asked for Col Richard La Garde's
address. Here it is.
I don't know where his office is now.

Can't you find out from Admiral Stitt
where Dr. Carter's old papers & letters are?
Some from Reed might be important.

Muscles in my arm are still quite
spastic at times and that accounts for
the messy places in this letter.

Hope you are all well Best wishes
from all the Trubys.
